Posts.Content: On Dec 11, 2014 10:41 PM formysister wrote: My younger sister just started chemo this week for stage 3 inflammatory cancer in one breast and stage one in the other. Her lymph node on one side was hard and sore but but on Friday they said it had not spread to the rest of the body.  Good news. Monday I was with her to get her port inserted, education at the oncologists office, and they did another scan on upper body late Monday afternoon. Tuesday was her first chemo treatment; I wasn't with her but she did fine. Now today they tell her they see something and want to do a CT Bone Biopsy.  It was scheduled for Dec 22;  her Dr called and said they are going to try and get her sooner. She tells us it's scary.  When I picked her up Monday we hugged she she I'M SCARED.  I tell her "I know". Hell we are ALL scared.  We aren't dwelling on it though. I posted Nelson Mandela quote about courage on her face book.  I texted her back "of course its scary! you are in a war for your life.  We will win this war. Do not let fear triumph." I was wondering what is the best was to keep her  positive through all this? What is the best thing to NOT say?  Absolutely, what the other ladies have said. Be there for her, she needs your support. Have her tell you all the things she would like to do and do them. Get her out of the house as long as she is strong, when they are in that room all day for days they get depressed and can't see the positive. DO NOT push her to continue on with any treatments she may no longer want. We as family members want them here with us, but the truth is they are the ones that are getting poked and proded. Feeling ill with chemo, not being able to get up and do things because she is so weak. Please respect her decisions, after all it is her body. You are already giving her support by logging on with us, you've come to a very blessed site. These people have been my distant family every since I became a member in September. God bless you, your sister, and other family members:) Mary
Posts.Title: How do I encourage my sister? She just started chemo

Posts.Content: On Nov 22, 2014 2:33 AM sparklyeyes88 wrote: I'm 26 married with 2 children under 5 just found out today my mom has been diagnosed with breast cancer they don't know what stage yet she has to go for an MRI to find out more I'm an only child and feel totally alone and scared ... I always say don't worry till you have to worry. Right now , it's just an diagnosis. My mother was diagnosed in 2009 with Breast CA, it was the very beginning stages and she freaked herself out with worry. She thought she was going to die, she had surgery and radiation and she made it. Unfortunately Pancreatic CA took her life this year. So you see, the cancer she was worried about did not take her life. Hearing the word cancer scares everybody and people tend to think it's the end. There are so many survivors out there. Good luck to you and your mom, God bless.
Posts.Title: just found out my mom has breast cancer

Posts.Content: On Oct 13, 2014 10:10 PM feedback09 wrote: My good friend died on Sunday 12th October from Breast Cancer. She was told she was cleared 1 year ago, i only spoke to her last week and she told me she was fine but died a week later. I know if she thought she was going to die she would of told me. I cant see her facebook page either and any remeberance messages because she unfriended me when i was a bit slow on replying to a message. It's far from her not liking me but more down to the releationship we had. We was soul m8s i think. Death has never hit me like this and i am lost and dont know what to do this is the most devestating thing i have ever had to do. We had a relationship a few years back and we lived together did a lot together but in the end we was not right for each other, but we still had very strong feelings and a relationship as friends. She was and is a shining star in the darkest night skies, she dedicated her life into helping the disabled and people. Even throughout the cancer she kept smiling like she always did and never let it get her down. She was only 41 and i feel like i have lost a big part of my life. I just dont understand how she died so suddenly its beyond me. I never thought when i went out with her, i would lose her 7 years later. I wish we found the cancer then. Any advice woule be good as i am broken,destoyed and sadness is not even close to how im feeling right now. I lost my soul m8 to Cancer and it sucks. Sorry to hear about your friend, I lost my mother the same day Oct 12th from pancreatic cancer. I know you feel lost because you had no closure, just pray and pray about it. She will come to you in your dreams to tell you and comfort you. When my sons father passed away, I was full of unanswered questions until he came to me in a dream and gave me the comfort that he was okay and everything was all good. I'm hoping you will get your answers that way. Once you do, you will be able to move forward. I wish you the best, I know this has to be hard for you .

Posts.Content: On Oct 09, 2014 7:24 PM dorisann wrote: I am sorry to read about your dear mother and continue to pray for her. Bless you both and your family . This is a very hard time. I kept my mom home until the end and I was so glad I could do that for her. You can always take comfort in the fact that you were there for Merie. My friend passed this morning. Two and a half months after being diagnosed with stomach cancer and having malignant ascites. Her husband wrote me that he feels her primary dorctors let her down because they diagnosed her problem as acid reflux and treated that for a couple of months. Also I don't understand why her urologist did not test her for cancer. She was under his care for five years taking that awful tamoxafin. I surely wonder if that drug gave her the stomach cancer in the first place. Take care dear. My heart goes out to you. You are a wonderful daughter. My condolences to you and her family:( I hate to hear stories about the doctors misdiagnosing patients, makes you always wonder if people could have stood a chance. My uncle, which is my mothers brother also had stomach cancer, he had surgery and passed away. The stomach cancer wasn't what killed him, it was his heart. They had removed the cancer. I was just thinking maybe it was his time. I also wonder why my mother didn't get checked thouroughly as well. It was her new primary care doctor that found her cancer. The tamoxifen is a very scary drug and I don't think I will ever take it, if I ever had to. I have decided to keep my mama at home till the end. I can't even imagine the people in the nursing homes trying to take care of her. I just pray that god releases her from suffering. God bless you. Thank you, I really am trying my best.

My son ate one for the first time about 3 years ago, and he said ''Mom, you have got to taste one of these, they are awesome!'' Posts.Title: My best friend

Posts.Content: On Sep 29, 2014 10:06 PM dorisann wrote: 5 and 1/2 years ago my best friend had a tiny lump that she was told was cancer. She went for surgery and was told the lump had disappeared. They found lymph nodes with cancer and removed them under her arm. she had chemo and started tamoxifen. She celebrated when her 5 years was up. Now 6 mos later she was diagnosed with stomach cancer and has malignant ascites with prognosis of 4 mos to live. I searched for info and have read studies in the UK and Sweeden mention tamoxifen can possibly cause stomach cancer. She also has a blood clot in each lung which this drug is known to cause . I keep wondering if the drug did this to her. I am hearsick over this and just cannot believe her prognosis. She will try chemo if she can handle it (so far side effects are bad for her). Does anyone have any thoughts on this story. Thank you. Hello, my mother was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2009, she had the lump removed, had radiation, and she also was on her 5th year of Tamoxifen when we got struck with Pancreatic Cancer. I am also wondering if this drug had anything to do with this cancer arriving. My mother was diagnosed in March of this year, I think we are nearing the end of our battle. She is bedridden and in diapers. I remember her breast cancer oncologist was not a fan of the tamoxifen, but we were sold on the whole keeping the cancer from coming back. She decided to take the drug. I'm wondering the same thing.

Posts.Content: On Sep 30, 2014 1:31 AM dorisann wrote: Thank you for replying. I am so sorry about your mom and will put her on my prayer list. We hear so much about drugs that are approved by the FDA and later found to be detrimental to our health. I don't know who to believe any more. I feel money is number one and they just don't care about the people at all. I was especially curious as to how that small lump my friend had actually disappeared. I know this can happen, have read of some cases, but then I did not read those people had nodes with cancer at the same time and had them removed. I am to the point that I even question mamography. Too many false positives and retesting going on including biopsy. I feel if a lump is not found and disappears, maybe that is a good thing without doing anything about it at all. I don't really know, but I know I am sick wondering if my friend could have lived many more years had she never had that mammogram. You're welcome for the reply:)I know, we get to thinking maybe we shouldn't take these meds. My co worker also had breast cancer and she waited months before taking the tamoxifen, because she saw all the side effects. I also believe these cancers are coming from the foods we eat. I was born in 76 and I remember the foods not having all the hormones in it. Kids actually looked like kids. These children are developing so fast these days. Everywhere you turn somebody has cancer, even these babies. Food actually tasted like food back in the day. Now with all these pesticides, things have an awkward taste. It's sad because all the healthy organic foods are so expensive, and it makes it hard for families to eat healthy. Thanks for adding my mama on your prayer list. I pray that your best friend will come by a miracle. I thought my mother was passing away last wednesday, today it's like she never had an episode. I guess god said not right now. She is back to her normal self, except for the fact she can't get out of bed. Hmmmm that is really suspicious about your friends lump. I honesty do believe that patients get misdiagnosed all the time. These med they prescribe for us always has some effect on our bodies. But to feel better and to heal we have to take them, such as antibiotics. I think a lot of people will skip out on that tamoxifen now and in the future.
